input: This is a comment.
This is another comment.
Yet another comment here.
Don't forget to comment your code!
Comments help improve code readability.
Adding comments makes it easier to understand the code later.
Good code should be self-explanatory, but comments can provide extra clarity.
It's important to write clear and concise comments.
Make sure your comments are up-to-date with the code.
Avoid redundant comments that only repeat what the code is doing.
Comments should explain why something is done, not just what is done.
Use comments to document any assumptions or constraints.
Consider using docstrings for function and class documentation.
Comments should be written in clear and understandable language.
Don't overdo it with comments; use them sparingly and judiciously.
Review and update comments as needed during code reviews or refactoring.
Comments can also serve as placeholders for future improvements or optimizations.
Make sure comments are consistent with the code and don't contradict it.
Use comments to explain any non-obvious or tricky parts of the code.
Remember that comments are for humans; the interpreter ignores them.
Keep comments concise, but provide enough information to understand the code.

Consider using comments to indicate areas of the code that need improvement or optimization.
Don't be afraid to refactor code to make it more self-explanatory and reduce the need for comments.
Use comments to document any workarounds or hacks in the code.
